p: International research among MSM has identified barriers to PrEP uptake across multiple domains characterized by PrEP attribute, individual, interpersonal, and structural barriers. PrEP attributes are the most commonly cited barriers to PrEP use among MSM, particularly concerns about PrEP’s cost, efficacy, and side-effects [ 14– 20]. Individual barriers to PrEP use include low perceived risk of HIV infection [ 14, 21– 23], concerns about daily adherence [ 17, 20, 23, 24], and the potential for increased risk of other sexually transmitted infections due to decreased condom use as a result of PrEP use [ 19, 20]. With respect to interpersonal barriers to PrEP use, prior work has documented concerns that sex partners may expect condomless anal intercourse (CAI) in the context of PrEP use [ 20], as well as fears that PrEP users may be perceived as sexually promiscuous [ 21, 25– 27] or HIV-positive [ 18, 24, 28] if others see them taking PrEP. Finally, structural barriers that limit healthcare access can also significantly impact PrEP use. For instance, stigma towards sexual minorities often limits the willingness of MSM to discuss sexual health and HIV prevention with healthcare providers (HCPs) [ 25– 27], which may inhibit their ability to access PrEP [ 29].
